question.text: Which of the following does not illustrate the anomalous properties of lithium?

options.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Li</mi></math> is much softer than the other group first metals
The melting point and boiling point of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Li</mi></math> are comparatively high

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Li</mi></math> forms a nitride <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">i</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mi mathvariant="normal">N</mi></math> unlike group first metals
The ions of <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Li</mi></math> and its compounds are more heavily hydrated than those of the rest of the group first elements

solution.text: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Li</mi></math> is much softer than the other group first metals. Actually, <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>Li</mi></math> is harder than other alkali metals.
